Your soul is nothing more than everything you can observe within you: your feelings, sensations, thoughts and imagination. Soul is nothing more and nothing less than that. Where people go wrong is by imagining “a soul”. This leads them astray. There is no truth in imagination. Stop picturing your soul and instead observe it, directly by silently, patiently, acquainting yourself with your inner reality. That means you have to attend inwardly without giving in to the habit of unconscious thought. It is by thought and imagination that the soul hides from itself, cloaks itself in false images and idols and worships those. Learn to attend to what-is within. Your spirit is nothing more than that which acts within you that cannot be observed directly, or that appears as “nothing”. You cannot know the spirit (or ghost) until you know the soul. Spirit is too close. It is the pure subject (being or observer) in you. Whilst you continue to believe that the soul is something other than the sensations and thoughts within you (your tangible but private inner experience) you cannot hope to identify spirit, for spirit has nothing tangible within it. Spirit is recognised by its effects. The soul overlaps the physical body (which is nothing more than the body revealed by your senses; and is public and tangible). This overlap is experienced as bodily sensations such as hunger, physical pain etc. Part of the soul that does not overlap with the physical body relates to itself. It does this when it daydreams, worries, judges or gets emotional, or (more rarely) rests in quiet contentment. It is clear in each of these examples that there is a sense of self or selfishness in this level of the soul. This is the part of ourselves we are responsible for straightening out. This is where we have our work cut out. Another part of the soul overlaps with the spirit, which, remember, is that part of us which has no tangible content, but nevertheless acts. One example of the spirit is your attention. You can show this to yourself by trying the following: Without moving your eyes, direct your attention so that as well as looking at these words (don’t stop reading!) also, notice the periphery of your visual field… Did you notice that your attention got broader? It shifted from narrow to wide focus, didn’t it? But what moved? Nothing tangible! Now, whilst continuing to read, notice the sounds around you… did you do it? Again, What moved? What shifted? Nothing you can ‘see’ or ‘sense’ - nothing tangible. The attention is like the zoom lens in a camera as you look through it. You can’t see the lens, but you can detect its presence as it shifts focus. The attention is like this. It is obviously a real part of you, but it has no directly tangible qualities, nor personal or selfish attributes. It is a ghostly or spiritual aspect of your being. You experience the spirit in you when you are suddenly inspired, or get an insight out of nowhere. Where did that come from? You can’t will inspiration or insight. Anyone who has suffered writers block will tell you that. It comes when it comes. That is the spirit. You can’t detect inspiration directly, but you recognise it in its action or effect on your soul. Take the writer experiencing writers’ block: they turn ideas over in their mind (thought), they assess and judge their ideas, they put some down on paper and read them back to themselves… all of this is soul activity. No matter how hard they try, nor how cross, frustrated or despondent (soul qualities) they get, they know they have not clinched it. Then suddenly, perhaps in the middle of the night, often when they are no longer thinking about it… bam! A bolt from the blue: Eureka! They’ve got it… That’s the Spirit. You don’t do inspiration, it does it to you. One more: if you learn to quietly attend to the sensation inside every part of your body, you will gradually awaken the part of your soul that is able to receive the intimations of the spirit directly. As you learn to prefer being still within to thought and emotion you awaken the part of the soul that can recognise the spirit. One thing you can realise as you do this is that your habitual awareness is partial. That is, you have a lifetime habit of attending to only part of your being at a time (a thought, an object in your field of vision, a sensation that is bothering you…) As you learn to broaden your attention to be aware of as much of your being as possible awareness turns into consciousness. You can only be aware of anything because consciousness is already conscious of it. Consider this: when you are reading intently, and are apparently unaware of your peripheral vision, how come you immediately notice if something moves in the corner of your eye (the cat, your mug falling over, a snake slithering into view)? Your consciousness is already looking at the entire field of vision, is already attending to your whole field of hearing, is already attending to every sensation and movement of thought within. Consciousness is an aspect of the spirit: pure 360 degree observation, permanent and effortless. Only the stilled, silent soul can recognise the spirit. Only when the soul gazes long enough on the spirit and is surrendered enough to find rest in contemplation of that spirit - it’s love - can the spirit reveal the truth of God, for God is the reality behind the spirit, the nothing behind consciousness, the nothing behind everything, the beloved of the spirit. It’s behind you now. How do I know this? Because I have done what I had to do. I have sufficiently cleared the selfish soul, found the love of the nothing that was always there, and, by grace, been shown this truth. Now, it’s your turn.
